They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 16.232 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 16.733 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.533 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 16.232 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 16.733 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.533 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.504 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 5.204 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.733 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.504 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 5.204 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.733 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.759 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 17.260 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 18.844 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.759 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 17.260 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 18.844 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.978 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.508 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.689 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.978 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.508 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.689 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 21.511 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 20.504 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.905 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 21.511 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 20.504 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.905 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 11.276 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.911 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 14.711 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 11.276 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.911 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 14.711 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.111 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.231 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.578 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.111 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.231 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.578 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 5.978 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 5.065 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.311 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 5.978 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 5.065 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.311 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.289 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.511 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.050 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.289 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.511 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.050 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 18.044 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.622 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 17.065 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 18.044 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.622 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 17.065 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.572 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 14.856 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 17.867 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.572 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 14.856 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 17.867 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 13.511 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.689 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.450 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 13.511 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.689 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.450 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 8.313 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 10.111 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.404 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 8.313 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 10.111 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.404 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 16.000 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.467 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.223 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 16.000 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.467 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.223 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 11.378 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.276 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.354 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 11.378 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.276 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.354 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.622 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.711 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 8.066 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.622 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.711 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 8.066 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.911 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.098 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.778 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.911 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.098 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.778 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.333 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.490 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.333 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.490 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.133 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.351 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.000 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.133 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.351 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.000 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 11.044 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.374 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 7.937 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 11.044 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.374 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 7.937 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.166 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.733 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.333 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.166 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.733 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.333 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 7.121 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.244 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.346 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 7.121 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.244 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.346 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.145 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.533 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.145 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.533 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.080 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.133 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.080 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.133 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 20.751 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 25.311 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.730 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 20.751 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 25.311 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.730 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 20.937 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 16.533 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.533 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 20.937 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 16.533 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.533 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.263 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.578 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.444 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.263 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.578 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.444 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.107 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.107 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.289 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.244 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.631 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.289 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.244 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.631 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 10.061 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 13.044 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.444 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 10.061 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 13.044 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.444 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.778 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.159 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.202 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 1.778 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.159 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.202 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.600 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.540 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 22.933 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.600 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.540 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 22.933 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.467 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.954 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.467 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.954 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.115 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.167 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.933 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.115 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.167 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.933 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="160"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="100"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr><th align='center' colspan='5' style='background-color: silver'><span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span></th></tr><tr><th align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Phenotype</th> <th align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Expected</th> <th align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Observed</th> <th align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Calculation</th> <th align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Statistic</th> </tr><tr><td>&nbsp;Yellow Round (Y&ndash;R&ndash;)</td> <td align='center'>90</td> <td align='center'>76</td> <td align='center'><sup>(76-90)&sup2;</sup>&frasl;&nbsp;<sub>76</sub></td> <td align='center'>2.579</td></tr><tr><td>&nbsp;Yellow Wrinkled (Y&ndash;rr)</td> <td align='center'>30</td> <td align='center'>25</td> <td align='center'><sup>(25-30)&sup2;</sup>&frasl;&nbsp;<sub>25</sub></td> <td align='center'>1.000</td></tr><tr><td>&nbsp;Green Round (yyR&ndash;)</td> <td align='center'>30</td> <td align='center'>42</td> <td align='center'><sup>(42-30)&sup2;</sup>&frasl;&nbsp;<sub>42</sub></td> <td align='center'>3.429</td></tr><tr><td>&nbsp;Green Wrinkled (yyrr)</td> <td align='center'>10</td> <td align='center'>17</td> <td align='center'><sup>(17-10)&sup2;</sup>&frasl;&nbsp;<sub>17</sub></td> <td align='center'>2.882</td></tr><tr><td colspan='4' align='right' style='background-color: lightgray'>(sum) &chi;&sup2;&nbsp;=&nbsp;</td> <td align='center'>9.890</td></tr></table> <br/> <hr/> <p>Your lab partner is trying again (eye roll) and did another a chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) test on the F<sub>2</sub> generation in a dihybid cross based on your lab data (above). They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.325 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.711 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.890 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.325 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.711 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.890 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.978 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.756 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 10.215 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.978 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.756 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 10.215 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.120 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.489 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.244 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.120 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.489 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.244 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.538 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.044 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.844 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.538 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.044 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.844 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.333 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.134 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.533 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.333 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.134 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.533 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.525 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 16.800 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.381 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.525 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 16.800 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.381 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.067 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.400 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.111 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.067 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.400 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.111 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 29.444 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.883 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 24.222 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 29.444 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.883 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 24.222 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.249 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.252 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.249 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.252 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.000 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.600 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 10.536 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.000 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.600 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 10.536 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.746 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 32.467 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 24.962 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.746 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 32.467 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 24.962 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect
