They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.933 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.400 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.181 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.933 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.400 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.181 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.497 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.497 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.911 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.224 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.579 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 3.911 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.224 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 4.579 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.022 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.131 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.711 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = -0.022 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.131 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 2.711 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.778 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.689 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.325 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 9.778 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.689 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.325 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 20.900 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.476 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 26.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 20.900 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.476 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 26.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.507 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.955 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 14.578 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.507 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.955 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 14.578 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect

They wanted to know if the results confirm the expected phenotype ratios.</p><p>You helped them set up the null hypothesis, so you know that part is correct, but they got confused and were unsure about how to calculate the chi-squared (&chi;&sup2;) value. So much so that they did it three (3) different ways.</p> <p>Before you ask your instructor for a new lab partner, <b>tell them which table is correct AND whether they can accept or reject the null hypothesis</b> using the information provided.</p>	A. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Correct	B. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	C. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 10.668 is correct and we <span style="color: #e60000;"><strong>REJECT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	D. <span style="color: #e69100;"><strong>Table 1</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 12.267 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	E. <span style="color: #004d99;"><strong>Table 2</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 0.667 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect	F. <span style="color: #b30077;"><strong>Table 3</strong></span> with &chi;&sup2; = 10.668 is correct and we <span style="color: #009900;"><strong>ACCEPT</strong></span> the null hypothesis	Incorrect
